PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual will be able to answer all questions exactly the same way another. Some questions will have to be answered by your experiences as an individual. For example, if you were born in a particular place, you may have lived there for many years, or you may have moved away from that place. The questionnaire is intended for persons who have personal experience of the pioneer years in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

No. In the early days we didn't need much going to town usually once a week to church (child on a school-house) on Sundays and visiting friends occasionally. We used either horse or mule as the only means of transportation, as river was open on our district so the original settlers came from Ontario and brought horses with them. My earliest memory of a summer driving cattle as a buckboard replaced about 1900 by a team. In winter sleds and sleighs were used in the early days, later juries and cutters were used.

In the early days we walked or hiked (hiked a good distance) on weekdays and coming home at noon and dinner time. We also drove a horse and buggy when we could afford one. We also used trains when available to go places. We also used a canoe when we had to cross rivers.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

My, in the early days we didn't have much going to town manually over a rough road. (Children walked.) Now we have a truck and making friends are automatically. We have water, dinner, and supplies. We have a telephone, electricity, and everything. We had a hundred and twenty-five acres of land, and we had a house built. We had a barn, a chicken coop, and a pig pen. We had a well, too.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes - About 1908 a store was opened at Bradshaw but mostly the people preferred the old store as it was closer to all their needs. Bradshaw was 4 miles N by W of my home and was used daily. Bradshaw's population was 400 in 1906, and I lived there until about 1905.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggested, (2) place-name (or origin and meaning of the name) (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change.

Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

My mother once said the name "Kingswood" for my local school which was a small village. It was named after a place near England called "Woodland." About 1870, "Springfield" (which was an old school name) became "many schools," and "Glenburn" and "Glenwood" were added to the land. Both "Ogden" and "Butte" and "Mullan" (both old places) also came into the area.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes. Usually go when there was more farmland and cattle, then young people moved away to get away from farming.

35. Did you move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

No, only a few, not many.

My mother bought the name "Hayswood" for our local school which was established in 1890. It was named after a pioneer who came from England and died in 1890. He was named "Hayswood" and his wife was named "Hayswood."
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes. Usually because other areas were more favorable.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person originating place-name (2) original and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3), (4).

My mother bought the "name" "Bullhead" for me when I was a child in what was called Bullhead School. She said she thought it would be a good name and also liked the idea of having a "new" school. It was named after an old trading post near Bullhead City and was originally named the land near a "bullhead" and "bullhead" rocks along the river. It was named after the river.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes. Usually because their area was flooded by flood.

35. How many people moved away during the 1960s? Did many return?

Quite a few, not many.
